originalTitle: Russian 'pick-up artist' accused of secretly filming women in Ghana
title: Being Kind and Safe in Ghana: A Special News Report!
content:
Hello everyone! Welcome to your special news from Africa! Today, we're going to talk about something very important: being kind, respectful, and safe. Imagine a beautiful country called Ghana. It's in Africa, just like many of our homes! Ghana is a place with lots of sunshine, yummy food, and friendly people who love to laugh and share stories. But sometimes, news can be a little bit tricky, so let's learn together about why it's super important to always ask for permission.

What Happened?

There's a story about a man who came to visit Ghana. People have said that he did something that made others feel uncomfortable. He is accused of filming people with his camera, but he didn't ask them first. Imagine someone taking your picture or filming you playing without you knowing or giving them a big 'yes'! How would that feel? Maybe a little bit strange or even a little bit sad. It's important to always ask for permission before you take someone's photo or video. It's just like asking before you borrow a toy from your friend. It's polite, and it shows you care about their feelings.

Why Is Asking Permission So Important?

Everyone has a right to their own space, and to decide what happens to them. This special space and choice is called 'privacy'. Your privacy means your body, your feelings, and your special moments are yours to share, or not to share. You get to choose! When someone films you or takes your picture without asking, they are not respecting your privacy. It can make people feel sad, scared, or even a little bit angry because they didn't get to choose. Think about it: Would you like someone to watch you eat your dinner without asking? Or play a game without asking if they can join? Probably not, because it feels a bit rude. It's always kind to ask, "May I take your picture?" or "Is it okay if I film this?" If someone says "no," it means "please don't." And everyone should listen to a "no." That's a super important rule! **Did you know?** Asking permission is called 'consent'. It means giving a clear and happy "Yes, that's okay with me!" If someone doesn't say yes, or looks uncomfortable, that means no, and we should stop.

How Ghana Is Helping

The people and leaders in Ghana want to make sure everyone feels safe, respected, and happy. So, the leaders in Ghana have asked another country, called Russia, for help. The man who is accused came from Russia. Ghana has asked Russia if they can send the man back to Ghana. This is not to be mean, but to understand what happened better and to make sure that everyone's privacy is respected. It's like when you have a problem at school, and your teacher helps everyone talk it out to find a fair solution. Ghana wants to make sure their beautiful country stays a very safe and happy place for everyone, especially for its wonderful people. They believe that everyone deserves to feel safe and have their feelings respected. Working together with other countries helps make the world a safer place for everyone. **Simple explanation:** When a country asks another country to send someone back to talk about what happened, it's like asking for help between big friends! They work together to do what's right.

What Happens Next?

The leaders in Ghana and Russia are talking to each other. They are working together to figure out the best way to handle this situation. It might take some time, just like it takes time to solve a big puzzle or bake a delicious cake. But the most important thing is that people are trying to do the right thing. They want to make sure that everyone in Ghana feels safe and happy, and that rules about respecting people's privacy are followed. It shows how much they care about their citizens and visitors.

Learning to Be Safe and Kind

So, what can we all learn from this story? It's a really important lesson for all of us, no matter where we live! **Rule Number 1:** Always ask before you take a picture or video of someone. Give them a chance to say yes or no. **Rule Number 2:** If someone says "no," or looks like they don't want their picture taken, you must respect that and stop right away. Their "no" is a full sentence. **Rule Number 3:** Your body and your space belong to you. No one should touch you, or film you, or make you feel uncomfortable without your clear permission. **Rule Number 4:** If anything ever makes you feel uncomfortable, scared, or sad, tell a trusted grown-up right away! This could be your mum, dad, a grandparent, a teacher, or another family member. They are there to help you and keep you safe! **Did you know?** The police are special grown-ups who help keep us safe in our communities. You can always talk to them if you need help or feel unsafe! Ghana is a wonderful country, and its people care deeply about being kind and safe. This story reminds us all how important it is to respect each other's privacy and feelings. Let's all try to be the kindest, safest, and most respectful friends we can be, every single day! Thank you for listening to our special news from Africa!
summary: Ghana is asking another country to send a man back because he is accused of filming people without asking, which teaches us why it's important to always ask for permission and respect everyone's privacy.
whyMatters: This is important because everyone deserves to feel safe and have their privacy respected, meaning no one should film or take pictures of you without your permission, and if something makes you uncomfortable, you should always tell a grown-up.

originalTitle: Can the UN Security Council be reformed?
title: Africa's Big Voice in a Big World Meeting!
content:
Hello, amazing kids of Africa! It's your friendly news reporter here, bringing you some super important news from far away! Today, we're going to talk about something really big that helps keep our world safe and fair. It's about how Africa can have an even bigger voice in a very important club for countries!

What is the United Nations?

Imagine you and your friends have a big club. You all meet to play games, share ideas, and make sure everyone is happy and safe. Well, the United Nations, or UN for short, is like a super-duper big club for almost all the countries in the world! From Ghana to Kenya, from South Africa to Egypt, lots and lots of countries are members. They meet to talk about big things like stopping wars, helping people who are hungry, making sure kids can go to school, and protecting our planet. It’s like a giant team working together to make the world a better place for everyone, including you! They want peace and happiness for all children. Did you know? The United Nations was started a long, long time ago, after a big war, to try and stop big wars from happening again! Its main job is to promote peace and safety around the globe.

The Special Peace Club: The Security Council

Now, within this huge UN club, there's a special, super-important team called the Security Council. Think of it like the captain's table in your school cafeteria, where the most important decisions about keeping lunch fair and peaceful are made. The Security Council's job is to keep peace and safety all over the world. When there's trouble or fighting somewhere, the Security Council talks about it. They try to find solutions to make things peaceful again. They make big decisions, like asking countries to stop fighting or sending helpers to places that need peace. It's a very powerful group, and their decisions affect many, many people and countries. Did you know? The Security Council has 15 members in total! But only 5 of them are 'permanent' – meaning they always have a seat at the table, no matter what! These permanent members have a very special power to say 'no' to decisions.

Where is Africa's Seat?

Here's the tricky part, my wonderful African friends. Africa is a giant continent! It's so big and has so many amazing countries and people. But on that very special Security Council, Africa doesn't have a 'permanent' seat. What does 'permanent' mean? It means some countries always have a spot, like having your own special chair at the dinner table every single day. Other countries take turns sitting there, like when you share a chair with a friend for a little while. But Africa, with all its beautiful countries and unique ideas, doesn't have a permanent seat. This means that sometimes, when very important decisions about peace and safety are being made, especially decisions that affect Africa, our continent doesn't always have its own voice sitting there all the time. It's like having a big family meeting, but one of the biggest family members isn't always at the main table to share their thoughts and help make the best decisions for everyone.

Why Is This Not Fair?

The boss of the whole UN, a very kind and wise man named Mr. António Guterres, says that this is 'indefensible'. That's a big word, right? What it means is, it's just not right, it's not fair, and there's no good reason for it! He thinks it's wrong that Africa doesn't have a permanent seat. Imagine you're playing a game, and there are many players. If one big group of players doesn't get to help make the rules, even though the rules affect them a lot, that wouldn't feel fair, would it? Everyone should have a say, especially when it matters to them. Mr. Guterres believes that Africa should always have a strong, consistent voice at the peace-making table. Because Africa is a huge continent with many countries facing unique challenges and having wonderful ideas to share, it absolutely deserves to be there all the time. Did you know? Africa is home to over 1.4 billion people! That's a lot of voices and ideas that should be heard on big world issues!

Why Africa's Voice Matters So Much

Africa is not just big; it's also very important to the world. Many of the peacekeeping missions that the UN sends out to help stop fighting are in Africa. African countries also contribute many brave soldiers and helpers to these missions. So, if decisions about peace are being made, especially about peace in Africa, who better to help make those decisions than someone from Africa? Our continent has so much to offer. African leaders and people have special understandings and experiences that no one else has. They know what works best for their communities and their continent. Just like you know what's best for your own toys and games! If Africa has a permanent seat, it means our continent's ideas, feelings, and smart solutions will always be heard loudly and clearly. This will help make sure decisions are truly fair and helpful for everyone.

What Does "Reform" Mean?

The big question everyone is talking about is 'reform'. Don't worry, it's not a scary word! 'Reform' just means changing something to make it better and fairer. It's like when you fix a broken toy or change the rules of a game to make it more fun for everyone. So, when people talk about 'reforming' the UN Security Council, they mean changing how it works. They want to make it more modern and more representative of the world we live in today. The world has changed a lot since the UN started! They want to make sure that continents like Africa, which are so important, get a fair chance to be part of the most important decisions, not just sometimes, but all the time! It's like updating an old game so everyone gets a chance to play and win, making it a better game for all players. Did you know? Africa has 54 different countries! That's more countries than any other continent! Each one has its own special culture and ideas.

Why This Matters for You, Amazing African Kids!

You might be thinking, 'Why is this important for me?' Well, my friends, it's super important! When Africa has a strong voice at the big world table, it means that decisions made there will be better for Africa. This can mean more peace in our communities, more help for schools, better healthcare, and more opportunities for everyone, including you! It means that the future you grow up in will be shaped by voices from your own continent, people who understand your dreams and challenges. It means fairness for Africa, and fairness makes the world a happier and safer place for all children to grow up. When Africa's needs are heard, it helps build a better future for every child on this amazing continent.

A Hope for a Fairer Future

Many leaders from Africa and around the world are working hard to make this change happen. They want to see Africa take its rightful place as a permanent member of the Security Council. It's like many people are saying, 'Hey, let's make sure everyone gets a turn at the microphone, especially our friends from Africa!' It might take some time, like waiting for your favorite fruit to grow, but people are hopeful. They believe that soon, Africa will always have its own special chair at the table where the biggest decisions about world peace are made. And that, my friends, is a wonderful thing to look forward to! Did you know? Many African leaders meet regularly to talk about how to make Africa even stronger and better! This group is called the African Union, and they work hard for the good of all African countries.

Let's Wrap Up!

So, remember, the UN is a big club for world peace. The Security Council is its special peace team. And right now, many people think it's not fair that Africa doesn't have a permanent seat at that table. But many good people are working hard to 'reform' it, to make it fairer. This means Africa will soon have a much bigger, permanent voice in helping make the world safe and peaceful. And that's fantastic news for all of us here in Africa! Keep smiling, keep dreaming, and know that your continent is a big part of making the world a better place!
summary: The United Nations boss thinks it's unfair that Africa doesn't always have a seat at the main table where big decisions about world peace are made, and many people want to change this so Africa's voice is always heard.
whyMatters: This is important because when Africa has a permanent voice at the world's peace-making table, decisions will be better for all African countries and help make the world a fairer and safer place for kids everywhere.

originalTitle: The big VAR debate: with, without or change its scope?
title: Football Fun: What is VAR and Why Do We Talk About It?
content:
Jambo, football friends! Hello from your special news reporter right here in Africa! Today, we're going to talk about something super interesting that helps make our favourite football games fair and exciting. It's called VAR! Have you heard of it? Let's find out all about it.

What is VAR? A Super Helper for Football!

VAR stands for Video Assistant Referee. Wow, that's a long name! But it just means a special helper who uses videos to help the main referee during a football match. Imagine the referee is like a teacher in your class, and VAR is like another teacher watching closely to make sure everyone follows the rules. It's like having super eyes! VAR's main job is to help the referee make sure that very important decisions in the game are correct. Sometimes, things happen so fast in football that even the best referee might miss something. That's where VAR comes in! It's there to help get things right, so the game is fair for everyone. Did you know? The very first football game was played a very, very long time ago, even before your grandparents were born! And back then, there was no VAR at all!

How Does VAR Work? Like Watching a Video!

When a big moment happens in a football game, like when a team scores a goal, or someone gets a penalty, special referees in a room far away watch it again. They have lots of screens, like a cinema, and they can watch the game from many different angles. They are the VAR team. If they see something that the main referee on the field might have missed, or if they think a big mistake was made, they talk to the referee through a special earpiece. They say, "Hey, you might want to look at this again!" Then, the referee on the field can go to a special screen at the side of the pitch. They watch the video replay themselves! After watching, the referee makes the final decision. It's like asking your friend to confirm something you think you saw. Cool, right? Did you know? Football is played with a round ball, and you can only use your feet, head, or chest to touch it. Only the goalkeeper can use their hands inside a special area!

Why Do We Have VAR? To Be Fair!

Football is all about fairness. We want the best team to win because they played well, not because of a mistake. VAR was brought in to help make the game fairer. Before VAR, sometimes a goal might be scored, but a player was actually cheating a little bit, and the referee didn't see it. Or maybe a player was pushed inside the box, and it should have been a penalty, but the referee missed it. These big mistakes can change the whole game! So, VAR tries to catch these big, clear errors. It's like having a superhero for fairness in football. Did you know? A football match lasts for 90 minutes, but it's split into two halves of 45 minutes each. Plus, there's a little break in the middle for players to rest!

The Big Question: Do We Like VAR?

Now, this is where it gets interesting! Just like some kids love bananas and others don't, some football fans and players love VAR, and some don't. People who love VAR say it makes the game much fairer. They feel happy when big mistakes are corrected, and the right team gets what they deserve. But some people don't like VAR so much. They say it makes the game stop too often. When the referee goes to watch the video, the game pauses for a little while, and it can feel like a long wait. They say it takes away from the fast, exciting flow of football. It's a big debate! Everyone wants fair play, but they also want to enjoy the game without too many stops. It's like when you're playing a game with your friends, and you stop to argue about a rule; sometimes it makes the game less fun for a moment. Did you know? The biggest football stadium in Africa is in South Africa! It can hold thousands and thousands of people who all love football!

A Weekend Without VAR!

Recently, in a famous competition called the FA Cup, some football games were played without VAR. This was a chance to see what football feels like without the video helper. People watched these games very closely. Some fans said, "Wow! The game felt so much faster! There were no stops, and it was exciting from start to finish!" They enjoyed not waiting for decisions. It felt like football used to be, quick and always moving. But others said, "Hmm, I wish VAR was there. I think the referee missed a big mistake, and it wasn't fair for that team." So, even when VAR wasn't there, people still talked about whether it was needed or not! It shows that it's a really important topic for football lovers everywhere. Did you know? The FA Cup is one of the oldest football competitions in the whole world! It started way back in 1871, which is even older than your great-grandparents!

Making VAR Better!

Because there are different ideas about VAR, people are always thinking about how to make it better. Maybe it can be faster? Maybe the decisions can be clearer for everyone to understand? Football managers, players, and fans all want the same thing: fair and exciting football. They are talking about how to use VAR in the best way so that it helps without slowing down the game too much. Maybe the referees will talk to the fans directly about what they are seeing, so everyone understands. It's like when you learn something new, you get better at it over time! So, whether we have VAR, or we don't, or we change how it works, everyone wants football to be the most wonderful game in the world. And we, your friends in Africa, love watching it! Did you know? Football is the most popular sport in the world! Billions of people love to play it and watch it. It brings people from all over the world together! So, what do you think about VAR? Do you like having the video helper, or do you prefer the game to be super fast all the time? Keep loving football, my friends! See you next time!
summary: This news talks about VAR, a video assistant that helps football referees make fair decisions, explaining how it works, why it exists, and the different opinions people have about it, especially after some games were played without it.
whyMatters: This is important because VAR helps make football games fair, ensuring big mistakes are corrected, so everyone can enjoy the game knowing the rules are followed correctly.
